source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk4

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: However, a somewhat larger weight gain was observed in some cases for the higher silicon material.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: The increase in $\mathrm { F e / C r }$ ratio of $Z \mathrm { r } ( \mathrm { C r } , \mathrm { F e } ) _ { \mathrm { : } }$ precipitates with increasing iron content can be easily understood as due to the increase of atomic fraction of iron.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: There were systematic variations in both $\mathrm { F e / C r }$ and $\mathrm { F e / N i }$ ratios with contents of chromium and nickel.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Although it was reasonable that $\mathrm { F e / C r }$ ratio decreased with chromium content, the decrease of Fe/Ni ratio with chromium content was also observed.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: The size and density of precipitates did not increase significantly with chromium content (Table 4 and Fig. 11c).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Therefore the total amount of iron that has not precipitated as $Z \mathrm { r } ( \mathrm { C r } , \mathrm { F e } ) _ { 2 }$ must become greater for higher chromium content alloys.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Moreover, the atomic fraction of iron to the total of iron and nickel which can precipitate as $\mathrm { Z r } _ { \mathrm { 2 } } ( \mathrm { F e } , \mathrm { N i } )$ must be larger for higher chromium content; therefore a higher Fe/Ni ratio in $Z \mathrm { { r } _ { \mathrm { {  } } } ( F e , N i ) }$ precipitates can be expected.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: On the other hand, observed Fe/Ni ratios for precipitates became smaller as chromium content was increased.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: A similar tendency for variations of $\mathrm { F e / C r }$ and $\mathrm { F e / N i }$ ratios with nickel content was observed and the same explanations can be applied.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: These large variations of chemical compositions in second-phase particles were thought to be caused by the low solubility limit of iron, chromium, and nickel in the zirconium matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Although the chemical composition of the alloying elements changes widely, there would be little difference in their matrix content.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: On the other hand, as the solubility of tin in matrix is large, the tin content in matrix will change with its content.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Judging from these results, uniform corrosion properties seemed to be affected by solute elements but not by second-phase particles.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Precipitates in the oxide film on Zircaloy-2 (Alloy 0) were examined by TEM after testing for $7 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { h }$ at $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Some of the second-phase particles in the oxide film were oxidized to form an orthorhombic structure (Fig. 14).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Furthermore, they seemed to have little effect on the morphology of the oxide around them.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: It was confirmed that the increase of tin content decreased the uniform corrosion resistance of Zircaloys.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: For samples with different tin contents, the oxide on the specimens (after long term corrosion test) were examined by means of $\mathbf { X }$ -ray diffraction analysis and transmission electron microscopy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: By $\mathbf { X }$ -ray diffraction analysis on the outer surface of the specimens, two types of oxides (monoclinic and tetragonal $Z \mathbf { r } \mathbf { O } _ { 2 }$ ) were observed.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: From the intensity of the X-ray peak, however, the quantity of tetragonal $Z \mathbf { r } O _ { 2 }$ was very small compared with monoclinic $\mathbf { Z r O } _ { 2 }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: In addition, there was little change in the samples of different tin contents.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: To investigate the change of morphology in growing oxide, especially in the region of oxide/metal interface, a thin plate was sectioned from the oxidized specimens. These samples were mechanically ground and thinned using an ion-milling technique for identification by an analytical transmission electron microscopic technique.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: In the low tin alloy, electron diffraction pattern analysis showed that the oxide consisted of mainly monoclinic $\mathbf { Z r O } _ { 2 }$ , and small amounts of tetragonal $\mathbf { Z r O } _ { 2 }$ and cubic $\mathbf { Z r O } _ { 2 }$ were also observed.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Although some workers reported that some tetragonal $\mathbf { Z r O } _ { 2 }$ was observed at the metal/oxide interface (introduced by the increase in internal stress [1012]), tetragonal $\mathbf { Z } _ { \mathbf { { r } } } \mathbf { O } _ { 2 }$ was not observed in this study at the oxide/metal interface.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: the corrosion rate exponent in high temperature water at $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ exceeded that in high pressure steam at $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: the corrosion rate exponent in high temperature water at $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ exceeded that in high pressure steam at $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: The effects of alloying elements (iron, chromium, and nickel) on the uniform corrosion of Zircaloys were comparatively small within the variation of contents specified in ASTM standards

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: tin had a significant effect in increasing the post-transition corrosion rate

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: nickel increased the hydrogen pick-up fraction

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: The effects of impurity elements (carbon, silicon, aluminum, and phosphorus) on the uniform corrosion resistance of Zircaloys were negligible

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: Oxygen seemed to increase the corrosion rate exponent before transition

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: nitrogen seemed to increase weight gain but not the corrosion rate exponent

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: Zirconium-based binary alloys with iron, nickel, niobium, or tantalum showed excellent uniform corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: The corrosion behavior of these alloys was characterized by an indistinct corrosion rate transition

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: tin stabilizes the monoclinic oxide

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: the stress-relief caused by the transformation of the oxide from monoclinic to tetragonal or fcc structures might be related to the good uniform corrosion resistance without a rate transition

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: Two kinds of second-phase particles were observed in Zircaloys

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: the composition of these precipitates changed with alloy content

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk7
evidence_span: they appeared to have no effect on the uniform corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk8
evidence_span: The oxide layer becomes porous at a critical thickness. Open porosity increases from 0.01% at 10 μm to 3% at 100 μm.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk8
evidence_span: Open porosity increases from 0.01% at 10 μm to 3% at 100 μm.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk8
evidence_span: Between the outer porous oxide and the metal, a dense interlayer exists. This is only =30 nm in nodular oxide but has been found to be several hundred nm in uniform post-transition oxide.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk8
evidence_span: Between the outer porous oxide and the metal, a dense interlayer exists. This is only =30 nm in nodular oxide but has been found to be several hundred nm in uniform post-transition oxide.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk8
evidence_span: The barrier layer is obviously influenced by the crystallization of the oxide at the interface. This crystallization leads either to a columnar monoclinic, an equiaxed tetragonal, or to a fine equiaxed monoclinic oxide.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk8
evidence_span: The latter, which probably forms only under the mineralizing effect of hydrogen, was found in nodular oxide. It easily cracks at the grain boundaries.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk8
evidence_span: Well developed columnar oxide is seen in uniform oxide, when corrosion resistance is high.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_026_chunk8
evidence_span: The intermetallic precipitates influence the corrosion behavior significantly. They probably oxidize slowly.
